node.title: Using Colour in Data visualisation
node.description: Some thoughts on using colour when visualising data.
author: Gemma Ives

node.title: D3.js for data visualisation
node.description: A simple introduction to D3.js (Data-Driven Documents) - a powerful Javascript Library for creating interactive data visualisation in web browers by manipulating Document Object Model (DOM).
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Deploy Your Dash App
node.description: It is exciting to see your beautiful dash app running locally, but it would be even more interesting if  others can interact it over the web too!
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Visualising GM data with a Shiny dashboard
node.description: A shiny dashboard that lets users explore the relationship between socio-cultural and GM-attitudinal measures described in Mallinson et.al. (2018) - Why rational argument fails the genetic modification (GM) debate.
author: Gemma Ives

node.title: Interactive Notebook with Jupyter Widgets
node.description: Based on the post - 'Plots wth Python', using IPython's widgets for exploring code and UK accidents dataset interactively.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Learning path - Concept
node.description: Explore data visualisations through definitions, examples, videos, and relevant resources.
author: Dataviz Team

node.title: Learning path - Lab
node.description: Tutorials and guides on create data visualisations using different tools and languages.
author: Dataviz Team

node.title: Learning path - Workflow
node.description: Increase your research impact through reproducible data visualisation workflows.
author: Dataviz Team

node.title: Non-Numeric Data Visualisation
node.description: Data visualisation isn't just for numbers
author: Gemma Ives

node.title: Template for Shiny applications
node.description: A simple framework to get you started creating your own Shiny app
author: Gemma Ives

node.title: Urban Observatories hackathon
node.description: The University of Sheffield hosted a three-day hackathon aimed to begin tackling the complex challenges involved in coordinating analytics using data from urban observatories across the UK.
author: Joe Heffer

node.title: Choosing Between Common Charts
node.description: With so many charts to choose from, how do we know which type will present our data the most effectively?
author: Gemma Ives

node.title: Contribute blog posts - v1.4
node.description: (UPDATED on 02 July 2020) This article will guide you to setup a development environment, relevant steps for produce a blog post, and introduce  you to useful syntax for styling the blog post and adding resources such as images, videos, and codes.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Visualising data on the web with Python and Dash
node.description: Dash is a user interface library for creating analytical web applications. Those who use Python for data analysis, data exploration, visualization, modelling, instrument control, and reporting will find immediate use for Dash.
author: Jez Cope
Angus Taggart

node.title: Dash: Layout and interactive
node.description: Dash apps are built with two parts - 'layout' and 'interactive'. To help us understand these two parts, let's build a dash app step by step and explore  useful documentations around them.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Statistics for Dataviz
node.description: Statistics is the science of the collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation of data. Descriptive statistics helps us to summarise and describe data.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Plots with Python
node.description: Applying descriptive statistics.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Data Visualisation
node.description: What, Why, How, Where. Learn more by go through three different learning paths  which includes contents on explore data visualisations, tutorials and guides on creating data visualisation, and adopt reproducible workflow.
author: Dataviz Team

node.title: Hosting Jupyter Notebook
node.description: The Jupyter Notebook has become a very popluar web application for sharing and creating documents  that contain live code, equations, visualisations and narrative text. This article put together a  number of user-friendly pathways for running live, interactive Jupyter notebooks on the web, and  documentation on how to use it.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Visualisation templates for Python
node.description: A selection of visualisation templates for you to build a visualisation more quickly.
author: Yu Liang Weng

node.title: Simple data visualisations have become key to communicating about the COVID-19 pandemic, but we know little about their impact.
node.description: Helen Kennedy is Professor of Digital Society at the University of Sheffield. Her research traverses digital landscapes. She is especially interested in the datafication of everyday life.
author: Dataviz Team

node.title: Visualising high risk areas for Covid-19 mortality
node.description: Colin Angus recently demonstrated various visualisations that he had created for Covid-19 mortality on Twitter. Here he elaborates on his approach to this work.
author: Dataviz Team
